--- title: Dynamic Systems and the equations of state keywords: fastai sidebar: home_sidebar nb_path: "archive.ipynb" ---

{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
impulse-response-1

Because of time invariance, if we have another impulse we can expect the same response at this second time, and if we hit twice as hard, then the response is twice as large

impulse response-2

And now because of the superposition principle, the full response will be just the summation of the signals

impulse response-3

If we have a more complex signal (e.g. ramp) we can break it down to a sequence of impulses (the output is the response to each of the impulses)

impulse response-4


In practise, these impulses and responses will be infinitesimal, and we do the summation in the time domain we do a convolution $u(t) * H(t)$, where $H(t)$ is the impulse response of the system. This can be a difficult integration


If we use the Laplace transform however, and move to the s-domain then convolution becomes multiplication, and things become simpler.

- As a control engineer we would like to design our systems to be as close as possible to be LTI, or so that the non LTI parts can be ignored.
- So that the standard LTI tools can be used.
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
fig, ax = plt.subplots(1,1,figsize=(8,5))

time = np.linspace(0,20,100)

ax.plot(time, evaluate(invL(G1), time))
ax.plot(time, evaluate(invL(G1)+invL(G2)+invL(G3)+invL(G4), time)), 
ax.set_ylim(-.5, 1), ax.set_title('G1'), ax.set_xlabel('time (s)')

fig.tight_layout()
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def terrain(theta_rad, x_0, x_range):
    y_range = theta*(x_range-x_0[0])+x_0[1]-10
    close_triangle = (x_range[0], y_range[-1])
    x_range = np.append(x_range, close_triangle[0])
    y_range = np.append(y_range, close_triangle[1])
    X = np.matrix([x_range, y_range]).transpose()
    patch = plt.Polygon(X, color='yellow')
    return patch

x_range = np.linspace(int(position[0][0]), int(position[-1][0]), num=20)
patch = terrain(theta_rad=theta, x_0=x_0, x_range=x_range)

# initialization function: plot the background of each frame
def init():
    ax.add_patch(patch)
    return patch,

# animation function. This is called sequentially
def animate(i):    
    #line.set_data(time[max(0,i-2):i], position[max(0,i-2):i])
    x_min, x_max = position[max(0,i-2)][0], position[i][0]
    y_min, y_max = position[max(0,i-2)][1], position[i][1]
    line.set_data([x_min, x_max], [y_min, y_max])
    return (line,)


# call the animator. blit=True means only re-draw the parts that have changed.
anim = animation.FuncAnimation(fig, animate, init_func=init,
                               frames=len(time), interval=40, blit=True,
                               repeat_delay=10000, repeat=True);

HTML(anim.to_html5_video())

def terrain(theta_rad, x_0, x_range):
    y_range = theta*(x_range-x_0[0])+x_0[1]-10
    close_triangle = (x_range[0], y_range[-1])
    x_range = np.append(x_range, close_triangle[0])
    y_range = np.append(y_range, close_triangle[1])
    X = np.matrix([x_range, y_range]).transpose()
    patch = plt.Polygon(X, color='yellow')
    return patch

x_range = np.linspace(int(position[0][0]), int(position[-1][0]), num=20)
patch = terrain(theta_rad=theta, x_0=x_0, x_range=x_range)

## Car
# Rotate the image to match the slope of the terrain
car_image = rotate_cv_image("img/car-large.png", theta)
# Define the image
img_size = 136
axin = ax.inset_axes([3, 4, 2.3, 2.3], transform=ax.transData) # [x0, y0, width, height]
imobj = ax.imshow(car_image, extent=[0, car_image.shape[1], img_size, img_size+car_image.shape[0]], zorder=1)

theta = 20
# Rotate the image to match the slope of the terrain
car_image = rotate_cv_image("img/car-large.png", theta)
# Define the image
img_size = 136
car_wh = 2.3*3



# initialization function: plot the background of each frame
def init():
    ax.add_patch(patch)
    return patch,

# animation function. This is called sequentially
def animate(i):    
    #line.set_data(time[max(0,i-2):i], position[max(0,i-2):i])
    x_min, x_max = position[max(0,i-2)][0], position[i][0]
    y_min, y_max = position[max(0,i-2)][1], position[i][1]
    line.set_data([x_min, x_max], [y_min, y_max])
    
    car_x = position[i][0]
    car_y = position[i][1]
    axin = ax.inset_axes([car_x, car_y, car_wh, car_wh], transform=ax.transData) # [x0, y0, width, height]
    imobj = axin.imshow(car_image) #extent=[0, car_image.shape[1], img_size, img_size+car_image.shape[0]], zorder=1)
    axin.set_xticks([]), axin.set_yticks([]) 
    axin.axis('off')

    return (line, imobj,)
    
# call the animator. blit=True means only re-draw the parts that have changed.
anim = animation.FuncAnimation(fig, animate, init_func=init,
                               frames=len(time), interval=40, blit=True,
                               repeat_delay=10000, repeat=True);

HTML(anim.to_html5_video())

def terrain(theta_rad, x_0, x_range):
    y_range = theta*(x_range-x_0[0])+x_0[1]-10
    close_triangle = (x_range[0], y_range[-1])
    x_range = np.append(x_range, close_triangle[0])
    y_range = np.append(y_range, close_triangle[1])
    X = np.matrix([x_range, y_range]).transpose()
    patch = plt.Polygon(X, color='yellow')
    return patch

x_range = np.linspace(int(position[0][0]), int(position[-1][0]), num=20)
patch = terrain(theta_rad=theta, x_0=x_0, x_range=x_range)

def animate(i):

    car_y = position[i][1]
    axin = ax.inset_axes([car_x, car_y, car_wh, car_wh], transform=ax.transData) # [x0, y0, width, height]
    imobj = axin.imshow(car_image) #extent=[0, car_image.shape[1], img_size, img_size+car_image.shape[0]], zorder=1)

class LinearWrongCar:
    _g = 9.8
    
    def __init__(self, x0, params):
        self._x_1 = x0[0] # position (along the road)
        self._x_2 = x0[1] # velocity
        self._m, self._alpha, self._beta, self._gamma = params
        
    def step(self, dt, u, theta):
        self.theta = theta
        A = np.array([[0, 1], [0, -self._alpha/self._m*abs(self._x_2)-self._beta/self._m]])
        B = np.array([[0, 0], [self._gamma, -LinearCar._g*np.cos(self._theta)]])
        
        self._x_1 = self._x_1 + dt*(A[0,:]*np.array([[self._x_1],[self._x_2]]) + B[0,:]*np.array([[self._x_1],[self._x_2]]))
        self._x_2 = self._x_2 + dt*(A[1,:]*np.array([[self._x_1],[self._x_2]]) + B[1,:]*np.array([[self._x_1],[self._x_2]]))
        
    def measure(self):
        x = self._x_1
        v = self._x_2
        return (x, v)
    
    def inertial_measure(self):
        # Rotation matrix to get back to the inertial frame..
        R = np.array(((np.cos(theta), -np.sin(theta)), (np.sin(theta), np.cos(theta))))
        x_i, y_i = R.dot(np.array([[self._x_1],[0]]))
        v = self._x_2
        return (x_i, y_i, v)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
class WrongCar:
    _g = 9.8
    
    def __init__(self, x0, params):
        self._x_1 = x0[0] # position (y)
        self._x_2 = x0[1] # velocity
        self._m, self._alpha, self._beta, self._gamma = params
        
    def step(self, dt, u, theta):
        self.theta = theta
        self._x_1 = self._x_1 + dt*self._x_2
        self._x_2 = self._x_2 + dt*(-self._alpha/self._m*abs(self._x_2)*self._x_2 - self._beta/self._m*self._x_2 + self._gamma/self._m*u - Car._g*np.sin(theta))
        
    def measure(self):
        y = self._x_1
        x = y/np.tan(self.theta)
        v = self._x_2
        return (x, y, v)
{% endraw %}
